reviewText:
Early Access Review

Alright, first off: Don't judge this game by its tutorial level. It seriously sets the wrong tone as far as what you should expect (particularly in terms of story quality). That said, I love this game. In a time that the market is heavily inundated with low-quality indie cash-ins, Nevermind really shines.

The concept is this: You're a neuro-prober"
date: an inception-style therapist that can enter the minds of psychologically troubled clients to help them sort through and ultimately deal with their past traumas. A concept very nicely executed by way of subtle imagery and level design that actually makes sense in the context of the trauma you're dealing with (as opposed to just filling a creepy place with a bunch of zombies and calling it a day). Throw in some pretty great (but not necessarily final-product) voice acting and you've got a pretty atmospheric story and setting.\n\nGameplay mechanic is simple
voteText: it's not what you think) that slowly develop a narrative as to the events that led to the client's trauma. You earn each photo after completing a puzzle related to it. When you've collected them all
helpfulPercent: you're presented with a collage and tasked with arranging certain photos to tell the story while avoiding red herring choices meant to distract you.\n\nScare-wise
votesHelpful: the game is pretty tense. Don't expect constant jump scares (well
votesFunny: but the game hardly relies on them to deliver the fear) but rather a creeping
commentsCount: building sense of dread. Throw in the fact that the game supports a heart-rate monitor mechanic and you'll find your environment changing to compliment your nervousness.\n\nSo far
column16: Nevermind boasts a tutorial and first client
column17: but promises more in the near future (their Twitter feed is constantly abuzz with new information on content updates
column19: etc.). Definitely worth full price if you're looking for a horror game with some genuine effort behind it."

reviewText: This game is creepy and sinister, but it has a heart of gold. Though the game frightens you and scares you, it seeks to help you literally control your emotions and confront your fears. It has been great to see this game evolve from a rough demo to a polished product. I'm so excited that the game finally launched. Hooray for Nevermind. More games like this, please.
voteText: 99 of 118 people (84%) found this review helpful 3 people found this review funny

reviewText:
If you have not checked out Nevermind, I strongly suggest you do so if you fit under ANY of the following:

*You like Psychological Horror.

*You’re interested in the concept of the subconscious holding clues to aid in therapy.

*You have, or plan to get, a biofeedback device and want to try to take your coping to a game rather than the typical biofeedback software.

*You want to support a game headed by a female developer, created to explore whether games can fully stand on their own but also be used to aid those to whom Biofeeedback is actually helpful.

Nevermind prompted me to buy a cheap biofeedback device since I backed it on kickstarter and had early access. The stories are engaging, the biofeedback is fairly reliable. Some people argue that the ‘punish’ system doesn’t work but I think those people don’t actually have an anxiety disorder. When you start panicking in real life, things do start becoming blank to you. Fuzzy. They don’t quite match up. Everything is wrong and harder to figure out. If you get too upset in Nevermind, if you let your heart rate raise too high without paying attention to the warning signs that things are getting weirder, you can sometimes be yanked to a calming area to make you focus on relaxing again. But most of the time, when you start noticing things are harder to see, you can stop, breathe, and make things clearer again. So it’s not actually a ‘punishment’ system. It shifts the game world to the way the real world FEELS when you have an anxiety attack. But if you can calm down, you can see things clearly again and unaltered. You are rewarded for making yourself calm down. All in the safety of your own privacy so none of those humiliating “How many people noticed my brain went off-line just now?” questions.

The plot of the game is you work for a dream therapy company, essentially. You’re a doctor who uses advanced technology to dive in people’s memories/dreams. What you see there is the product of how the brain creates false memories to deal with traumatic occurrences or over-exaggerates fears in the subconscious. It’s your job to solve puzzles, figure out how to get through the level, stay calm while doing so, and collect ~10 memory “postcards”. At the end of your level, you try to take in what you’ve seen through the level and figure out the five postcards that are the ACTUAL reality of what happened to the patient. The tutorial level is simply a fairy tale to introduce people to the concept. Other levels deal with darker and very real topics but have always tried to be respectful to the sort of trauma they can induce. I’d give examples but if I did that, I’d honestly give away the solution to those levels.

I backed Nevermind because I believed in what she was trying to do - create games that actually can be used to help people like me gain control and yet are interesting themselves. I advocate others check it out because it is honestly a good game even if you DON’T have a biofeedback device to measure your heartrate. They really had to fight an uphill battle to get this game released (the first kickstarter didn’t quite make it) but it’s here now and it’s really well done.

reviewText:
As someone that has PTSD due to several instances while deployed to Afghanistan, this game hits the nail on the head.

For those with PTSD i'd reccommend this game to help you understand that you're not alone and people are going through the same problems and it can get better.

For those without PTSD I'd reccomend this game to help understand why people with PTSD act certin ways or why they seem distant, scared, anxious, or paranoid...

On top of spreading awareness, this is just a very well done puzzle game. If you really take your time you'll figure out the puzzles without too much stress and the stories are very well done. 10/10 Can't wait for more content to be released.

reviewText:
Yeah, not really as interesting or clever as I thought it would be...

Credit where it is due, there are two or three visually unique, rather impressive environmental designs...

...

But the game's short, very short and very unsatisfying...

There were two cases plus the tutorial, which, in total, took me a little shy of three hours...

...

If you think the price tag attached to this game justifies an experience which is one or two rungs above one of those Half-life 2 horror mods then I suppose you will be comfortable with this purchase...

Otherwise I recommend you avoid it...

reviewText:
What content there is, is actually extremely well made.

The problem with this game right now, however, is that despite more than a year in development only one level has been added to the game.  This means that the entire game is literally two levels, one of which was free to download in alpha form last year.  While following development, we were promised three to five levels.  The second level was added to the game in July.  With it now being October, I assumed that they would have added at least one, and probably more, clients before moving from early access to full release.

With only two total levels, and no obvious guarantee of any future content; I can't justify the current asking price.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

NOTE: This is reviewed on Early Access as of 4/1/2015 - will update when more levels come out.

Been a follower and fan of this game since its original Kickstarter back in March 2014 and am incredibly happy to see it on Early Access. This game has taken a great step up from the early version and is well produced.

Nevermind places the player in the mind or subconcious of a stressed patient, one who has suffered a sort of trauma that is still effecting them. Your job is to travel the subconcious mind and put the pieces together, figure out what happened, and help the patient reach clarity or a breakthrough. However, be wary as your presence in the mind is unwelcome, causing the world to fight back to your presence. Can you survive the inner walls of their mind and help them, or will you be consumed by fear?

As the game stands in Early Access it is a great treat to play, especially with the optional monitors that create your own fear response" - as you get more scared the gameplay changes slightly

votesTotal: Nevermind plays as a wonderfully surreal horror-adventure game. While only two levels are currently available they are well worth the time and money as a wonderfully unique experience that I hope is only the start from this great developer."

reviewText:
It's a fun game. Plays well, very interesting concept and story. Honestly, I love it.

But seriously? Only two cases? I helped with Nevermind's kickstarter. I was so pumped when I saw it was coming out. But I expected at least FOUR cases for that pricetag. I bumrushed the first case, as I'd seen it already, as most early supporters had. I had a good time with the second one, took my time... really explored. And then I went to pick the next one... only there was no next one.

If more cases are coming out, cool. But don't buy it until there's MORE. I topped out at 4 hours and that's stretching it.
voteText: 10 of 11 people (91%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Nevermind is a very short but satisfying game dealing with psychological trauma and working towards healing said wounds. Of the two patients you work with they are both relateable to some degree or another and you'll end up really feeling for them as you go through their fractured psyche. This is the type of psychological horror game that doesn't rely on jump scares or running from monsters beyond those imagined in the mind. The darkness surrounding everything is indicative of dealing with the pain and the surreal imagery adds that little something to showcase that the mind works in strange ways to try to cope with the trauma. By the end I found myself needing to play something a little more whimsical just to dust the cobwebs of depression out of my own head. My only problem is with the length of the game. With only two patients it's very short. I would have loved to have seen one or two more added to give a little more variety to all the types of mental illness out there. Still, it's worth playing despite the short length.

http://www.kickstartadventure.com/home/nevermind-review/
http://cliqist.com/2015/10/21/nevermind-takes-peek-subconscious/
http://cliqist.com/2015/10/23/nevermind-brings-surreal-eerie-images-life/

reviewText: Where to begin...       This game is amazing. I was blown away by the attention to detail, you really do have to pay attention and put it all together. This game manages to convey stories in such a unique and powerful way it is truely amazing, However I would like to also say this game does not live up to its true potential. It is VERY short. This is a major con and Almost made me give it a thumbs down. With that being said the only reason I give it a thumbs up is due to the astonishing and unique gameplay. So would I recommend you buy this? Yes, I would even despite the fact it is so short. The developers of nevermind have saidOriginally posted by Nevermind devs: our resources to build Nevermind allowed only for the three levels (IntroSim, Client #251, Client #418). This was actually always the amount of planned and promised content. That said, we're incredibly eager to build more levels (we already have several concepts ready for future Clients). Our capacity to build them will depend entirely on how well the game does in the next few months.\n\nIf Nevermind is successful enough to permit the development of an additional level, then the current plan is to provide it as a free download for anyone who has the game. We're all keeping our fingers crossed.  So I say screw it support them as much as you can they deserve it and this game is amazing
voteText: 11 of 13 people (85%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
For me, the little bit of time i spent with Nevermind was unforgettable. It left me wanting more. The devs seemed to have a knack for not just scaring you, but thrusting you into a situation that makes you feel down right uncomfortable. The game deals in heavy subject matter but is never disrespectful. One such case you undergo deals with a trauma that is near and dear to my heart. My mother experienced something similar to what this particular 'victim' experienced. I wont spoil it but, theres only two cases here to undergo not including the tutorial. Its the first case you undergo. A the one with the woman experiencing social anxiety i believe.
What I went through to help this patient was harsh and true. It broke me down and all at once i understood what my mother went through. It brought me to tears as i listened to the woman understanding where it all went wrong. The wonderful thing about this game is the end goal. Helping poor souls understand thier trauma and the final words they speak in the mission end sequence that gives you hope that they will find peace. Its something I've never experienced in an indie horror game. Where other games want to hammer home dread. This one seems oddly unique. The scares take a back seat to what the game really wants you to feel, compassion.
A beautiful, cerebral experience i will never forget. I truly hope this game goes far and its team goes far.
Thank you from the bottom of my heart for this truly therapeutic experience.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

**No Bioware Review**

Thrilling, challenging, lovely, and interesting! For early access, I am super impressed with how this game runs and how well the environments bring you to a totally new world that feels like its inside someone's head. Totally worth the 100 bucks I gave to Kickstarter already! If you can - then play this game, ESPECIALLY if you enjoy thinking, solving, exploring, and enjoying horror atmospheres.

No monsters, no enemies - but there are some jump scares and very creepy situations and environments.

Beautiful, terrifying, challenging, and interesting - this first person puzzel solver will have you begging for more! Even without any bioware to enhance the game, I still REALLY enjoy it! Totally worth 25 bucks!!

reviewText:
This was a spooky, atmospheric horror game, and overall I enjoyed it and would recommend it. Part way through the second level I realized that I had played that level before, probably during its time as a academic project, although it had evolved beyond that.

I played the first two levels without any biofeedback sensors. Before playing the third I picked up a Polar H7 heart sensor. It was certainly a different experience and I'd want to replay the game with it on but at some times it was almost unplayable for me so I had to disable the fear mechanic.

It wasn't that I was anxious or afraid or anything like that but rather that my heart rate was high and variable due to a short term condition. At that point no adjustments to the sensor sensitivity helped; it had my baseline at the yellow" fear level. This is new ground
recommended:
and  the support for the Polar H7 was more recently added so some difficulties are to be expected. I'll update my review once I've had a chance to play when my heart rate isn't all over the place.

Is the game short right now? Yes. It took me about 4 hours to beat it.

Is it well made? Yes. The environments and the narrative are very well thought out.

Was it worth it? For me it was. The game itself is good enough for me as-is but more than that it's a vote of confidence in the studio. They said that they plan on releasing more levels for free and I believe them but even if they don't
hoursPlayed: I won't feel like I lost anything."

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nNevermind is quite the innovative game in its field, bringing a whole new aspect to the horror genre. In Nevermind, the player plays as a doctor, whose job it is to enter the subconscious of the patients. Whilst playable without a biofeedback sensor, it's highly recommended for the enhanced gameplay - the game monitors your heart rate to determine how scared and/or stressed you are, which in turn increases the difficulty of the game. The game is certainly highly recommendable - even though in this early stage there isn't an awful lot of content, the simple yet well designed storyline for the first patient and the hauntingly beautiful design of the game and its atmosphere are enough to make you want to play for hours. I have high hopes for the future of this game and can't wait to play more.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ok, who's watched 'The Sixth sense' with Bruce Willis and was impressed with the surprise ending? Well i'm happy to say my first playthtough of this game gave me that same feeling. I could have kicked myself for not picking up on all the clues.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sSQCaegDAXo

Nevermind is a biofeedback-enhanced horror adventure game that takes you into the dark and surreal world within the subconscious minds of psychological trauma victims.

As you explore twisted labyrinths and solve the puzzles of the mind, an (optional) biofeedback sensor will monitor your feelings of fear and anxiety with each passing moment. If you let your fears get the best of you, the game becomes harder. If you’re able to calm yourself in the face of terror, the game will be more forgiving.

Nevermind’s goal is to create an unforgettable gameplay experience that can help teach you to be more aware of your unique internal responses to stressful situations. If you can learn to control your feelings of stress and anxiety within the disturbing realm of Nevermind, just imagine what you can do when it comes to those inevitable stressful moments in the real world… Recommended!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

There are points during Nevermind where I felt my stomach turning. I felt literally sick, and I cannot even imagine how this would have worked if I did have one of the sensors. Nevermind is disgustingly well made. Currently, the amount of content is quite low, but what is there is among the best horror fuelled gameplay that you can find, and there’s more on the way. Hopefully developer Flying Mollusk can maintain the level of quality and intensity present in the game so far and deliver a truly remarkable title. Nevermind is a game to keep your eye on if you are a horror fan. Just don’t expect the game to be friendly!

For my full EARLY ACCESS review, check out the following link: http://shoddypixels.com/indie-focus-nevermind/

reviewText:
The concept of diving into people's minds has been done before, like with Psychonauts and Inception. However, just because a concept has been done before does not necessarily mean it's a bad thing, and this game proves that. It delivers on many different feelings, from dread and panic, to hope, salvation, and true accomplishment... if completing puzzles with psychological themes makes you feel accomplished.


Story~: With regards to you (and the character you play), you are the newest doctor of the Neurostalgia Institute, skilled in the process of Neuroprobing, which lets you dive into the minds of trauma paitents and go through their sub-conscious minds to uncover what exactly lead them to the facility to be probed in the first place! At the time of this review, there were only three actual probings with puzzles to solve: an introduction story that was created to help aid new neuroprobers learn the tricks of their trade, a young female with scopophobia, and a homeless man taken in by the facility after a public episode.

Presentation~: Like with most horror games, atmosphere is key; if you lack that, your game lacks any true impact. It is fortunate then, that this game definitely delivers on the atmosphere, where it slowly builds up the weight of the dread the [shifting] environments places on your shoulders as you delve deeper into the subconsciousness of the trauma paitents. Unlike the introduction story, the first and second clients you tend to have very serious traumatic experiences that many people may have been unfortunate to deal with, be it a direct cause of their own actions, or being completely out of their hands, and the game treats these issues on a serious note. This dedication to detail of handling the traumatic experiences ties in very well to the gameplay, as well as how small things can have large implications.

Gameplay~: This is a psychological horror puzzle game. In every probing you conduct, you will begin in a safety hub that connects you to the rest of the subconscious mind, which includes a large board. This board will house the ten postcard photographs you will earn from completion of the puzzles, which in addition to that, will allow you to go further into the mind and expose the trauma bit by bit. Upon gaining the final postcard photograph, you will need to return to the large board and sort out the postcards so it tells the story of their trauma; only five of the ten tell this tell, the others are included to throw you off until you've gained all ten of them and can really piece it together. Unfortunately, at the time of this writing this review, I do not own a biofeedback sensor, which is an optional input device that would track your pulse to let the game know if you are getting frightened and anxious, punishing you by blurring the world around you if you do not calm yourself down, although they are kind enough that if you get too worked up, they pull you back to a safe room to take a breather and calm down before you return to the task at hand.
When you complete each probing, you are then allowed to replay the probings again, but this time to comb them thoroughly for clues that fill in the missing gaps of the trauma you just uncovered, adding to the game's replayability... and numbing you to the horrors within (except for one room in the first cilent's house; you'll know it when you encounter it...). The combing process will require you to reset the sessions you probe, although your discoveries will remain recorded, no matter how many times you may need to reset. Only a handful of the puzzles may baffle folks during their first runs of the various probing sessions, and even fewer instances of failure may occur, where the only punishment is being sent back to the safety hub to venture back to where you failed.


For the casual gamer, this is a short journey, more so if you remain calm and/or lack the biofeedback sensor. For the completionists, the repeats for combing the probe sessions will have you searching everywhere. Regardless of your stance to how a game is played, this is one that should be played... you may just learn something about yourself through it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I played it initially without a biofeedback sensor and was captivated by the story and the environment.  The music and environment are truly creepy and give me goosebumps through most of the levels.  The gameplay is simple in that there are only a small number of controls.  However, this simply allows you to focsu on the small details scattered throughout the environment to solve the game's puzzles.

I then bought a biofeedback sensor and that added a whole new layer to the game.  I had no idea my heartrate increased so much at various moments and you really have to force yourself to breathe and slow down so you can go on.

In summary, this is an amazing concept and what's complete is well executed.  I look forward to seeing it reach its potential when the developers complete the rest of the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The reality is that I have my doubts that this game will ever be worth $25, but that it is a fun experience and would undoubtably be improved if I owned one of the biofeedback devices.

Horror: As far as it's horror aspects, it is similar in atmosphere to Among the Sleep. Unlike in AtS, though, there are no enemies to hide from, but the overall graphical representation and great sound effects create a pretty spooky atmosphere.  There's really only one area so far with jump scares, so the game relies heavily on the visuals and sound, and it does a nice job.

Story: So far the story tells two stories: Hansel and Gretel, and the original story of a young woman who is coping with the childhood trauma of losing her father.  The original story is fantastic and left me really wishing that they had put the effort into creating another original story rather than the Hansel and Gretel one.  The HaG story is obvious from the moment it starts and really creates no tension or curiosity whatsoever.

Value: Here's main the problem, though. The game currently claims to have 2 levels, but one of them is the Hansel and Gretel tutorial. This wouldn't be a huge problem except that there is only one more level that will be coming for certain. Additional levels after that are dependent upon how well the game sells during early access.  Considering how much time and money (including a rather large and successful Kickstarter campaign and corporate sponsorship) it has taken to get us the 1 and a half levels that we currently have, I just have a hard time imagining that this game will get much bigger.   In it's currrent form, it took me 1 1/2 hours to complete what is available on my first playthrough.

The bottom line is that the one original story in this game is quite good and makes you want more.  Whether much more will be coming is very much up for debate.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As of this review, I have not completed the game yet (It's also midnight and im really out of it so I apologize if there are any mistakes, ill fix them later).  But from what I've played so far, I can tell you that this is definitely a fun game.



---MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS---

Nevermind takes you into the subconscious of trama victims.  Where you are then tasked with helping them remember what happened during their inccident. You will find many clues, some of which are red herrings.  The deeper you go into their mind, the creepier and more disturbing it gets.  There are several different patients each with their own tramatic experiences (with more to come soon).  Also, If you are like me and actually have Scopophobia, You are going to have a bad time with the first real patient (the one after the tutorial patient).

reviewText:
Disclaimer: This game is very, very short.

Nevermind is a lovely, well made, tought-provoking and original experimental videogame".
You play as some kind of futuristic "doctor" which is able to penetrate into the subconcious mind of the clients in order to evoke the memories of their traumas and help them overcome their PTSD (Post-Traumatic-Stress-Disorder).
Each of the 3 patients has his own backstory
hoursPlayed: and the player is tasked to walk along their memories
voteText: uncovering what happened
helpfulPercent:
and collecting "photos" reminding of the specific trauma.
The best thinng of the game is the very well crafted "dreamlike" feeling.
The sensation of being in a subconcious mind is very well achieved and the shifting thoughts of each person make the game very unpredictable.
The most amazing thing is that the game can sometimes be very scary and creepy
votesHelpful: but in such a shocking and original way you'll feel amazed (still
votesTotal: if you're oversensitive you might want to avoid the game
votesFunny: as well as other horror games).\nSpecially the second patient will leave you thinking of what you just saw for quite a while.\nYou are tasked to navigate the very "psychedelic" environments
column16: but most of the time you are just walking
column17: so the most appeling part of the game is the feeling of it and the journey itself.\nA fantastic thing is that
column18: unlike many other small experimental productions
column19: this game features properly good graphics! VFXs
column23: post processing effects...everything looks surprisingly convincing and some of the set pieces look like they have been pulled away from a true triple A game.\nEverything very good so far
column24: but unfortunately i have to talk about the worst thing of the title...\nThe game is very short; way too much according to my point of view.\nYou only have 3 clients to work with
column25: one of which is only a tutorial
column26: and if you have a good intuition you can complete the whole game in about 2 hours...Sure ther's a challenge mode unlocked after completing the game
column27: but it honestly isn't that interesting.\nThe author of the game promised some more content in the future and if at least 2 more clients will be added i will consider this experimental game a true success.\nI'm still glad i played it and i still recommend it
column29: but if i won't see any new content in about 6 months i'll probably change my review."

reviewText:
Nevermind is an interesting game. I didn't have a Biofeedback sensor so I am unsure how scary the game would have gotten for me as I am not good with horror games. What I do know is that after playing it without a Biofeedback sensor, I can say that the game does build great atmosphere, tension and does a good job of creeping me out, all while showing beautiful innovative visuals that reminded me very much of the twisted visuals of Layers of Fear, and if I am honest, I would rather be playing that. Not that this is a bad game, but Layers of Fear is a scary game, this isn't scary as such, more unsettling. I liked this, I liked the weirdness, the idea behind it. I liked that I was travelling into people's minds trying to resolve their depressive, ptsd disorders. I think this game could be a great tool if the testing on the idea goes ahead and is actually used to help people manage depression and anxiety. I think it's fantastic that they're trying to make something that will help people who suffer with such illnesses.

The beginning stages of the game are lethargic, text filled, slow, and make me feel like I am playing a walking simulator due to there not being a run button. The controls are terrible! Puzzles require keys to move the cursor rather than the mouse, what a stupid idea!

SPOILER: I completed this in 2.9 hours apparently, but 30 minutes of that was me wandering around aimlessly because I didn't realise I had completed the game. Only 2 full stories to tackle after the tutorial stage. I thought this was terrible. I expected much more longevity from this game and it failed to deliver on that note.

I don't know if they will be adding more cases to this game, I hope so because I would love to play more. My main disappointment with Nevermind is that I paid £7.50 per case (not including the tutorial), and I thought that for the money I would have been given more cases to resolve.

PROS:

- Creepy
- Atmospheric
- Surreal
- Great concept
- Innovative
- Interesting puzzles
- Powerful stories
- Being studied for health benefits
- You can use a Biofeedback sensor

CONS:

- What ending?
- Too short
- Controls are poor
- No jump, crawl or run buttons
- Not everyone has or can afford a Biofeedback sensor just to get the most out of a game.

If Nevermind had had more cases to solve, I could've overlooked some of it's flaws and given it a higher review score, but due to it's short nature AND the flaws, I can't give Nevermind more than a 6 out of 10. So do I recommend this game or not. Hard to say, the concept is great and I enjoyed playing it, but I felt let down by the end. This isn't a definite purchase by any means, but it has to be a maybe purchase. I think that all depends on the individual. I have done my best to highlight both sides of the coin as to give an impartial review. I hope you found this helpful, but for me, as I liked the atmosphere I would recommend this for people like myself.

reviewText: A moving psychological (horror?) adventure with great music and voice acting.\n\nIn Nevermind, you play as a doctor who goes into peoples' memories to help them uncover the source of their psychological trauma in a series of cases". It's a first-person game with some limited object manipulation in order to solve puzzles
hoursPlayed: are decently thought provoking. Your primary goal is to collect photographs in the patients' memory in order to sort out their memories.\nI would be hesitant to call this a horror game - though there's some unsettling imagery and shocks
voteText: it doesn't build a persistent
votesHelpful: nor is there much in the way of threats. It excels in evocative
votesTotal: dreamlike imagery - each patients' mind has a unique theme and recurring motifs that make them feel their own
votesFunny: and oftentimes they are relatively minor details which make the game feel like it had much attention devoted to it. Rounding out the games' strengths are the voice acting
column17: which greatly adds to the unique flair of each "case". When background music from a game is stuck in my head days afterward
column18:
I consider that an accomplishment on the games' part.
The only real weaknesses here are some very basic gameplay - walk and click is mostly what you're limited to - and the slow movement speed of the character (in some areas).

Nevermind is a great experience if you're in the market for some surreal imagery and a bit of a tug at the heart strings
column19: and don't mind pretty basic gameplay. If that sounds up your alley
column20: then I don't think you'll be disappointed
column21: as this game's strengths far outweigh its few weaknesses.\n\n**NOTE** - My long playtime is from the game failing to close and running idle for around five hours. There were no technical problems otherwise."
